item.title: 33 Immortals coming to Steam this summer
item.content:encoded:
• PC

Currently available via Epic Games Store and Microsoft Store.

Thunder Lotus Games will release the PC version of cooperative roguelike action game 33 Immortals via Steam this summer, the developer announced.

33 Immortals first launched in Early Access for Xbox Series and PC via Epic Games Store and Microsoft Store on March 18, 2024. It is also available via Game Pass.

It is currently unclear whether the game will still be in Early Access when it launches via Steam.

“Bringing 33 Immortals to Steam is an important milestone for us,” said creative director Stephan Logier in a press release. “The game has grown a lot through our first five updates, and we’re excited to keep building it with even more players joining the rebellion.”

Here is an overview of the game, via Thunder Lotus Games:

First released into Early Access in March on Epic Games Store and Xbox, the game has steadily evolved alongside its community, surpassing one million players since launch. The Steam release will deliver the most up-to-date version of 33 Immortals and mark the next step in the game’s ongoing journey following multiple content updates and improvements since launch.

Since its Early Access debut, 33 Immortals has continued to expand and improve through five major updates. These updates introduced new content and refinement across the experience, including additional gameplay features and quality-of-life improvements, all of which will be included in the Steam version.

Watch a new trailer below.

Steam Announce Trailer

item.title: The Climber Is An Incredibly Beautiful, Devastating Manga About Hubris
item.content:encoded:
The first time I encountered the word “egoist” was while watching the shonen sports anime Blue Lock. By all accounts, it was a solid first foray into how an (ego) death game-lite soccer tournament comprised of nothing but strikers would have hotheads butting heads. However, everything Blue Lock had to offer me might as well have been baby food by the time I finished the underappreciated seinen gem The Climber—a brutal, transcendent tale about when grit and enlightenment arrive a hair too late to save men already ruined by their own compulsions. 

Rather than being a glorified glossary of the sport like its breezier contemporaries, The Climber, written by novelist Jirō Nitta and adapted into a manga by Shin-ichi Sakamoto, is essentially about a group of climbers and the folly and pyrrhic victories of their impulses—namely, those of protagonist Mori Buntarō. When we first meet Mori, who’s loosely based on the real-life legend Katō Buntarō, he’s an edgy transfer student already halfway checked out of humanity. After a run-in with a classmate who impressively scaled the school roof just to poke fun at Mori for being an antisocial prick, Mori repeats the climb, to the horror of everyone at the school, without a belaying rope. The instant he pulls off a ballsy double dyno jump to the school roof, Mori’s life shifts into a new paradigm as he chases an insatiable high for climbing, a sport the manga frames as his supposed salvation.

At the onset, Mori’s got everything your typical shonen protagonist would have: a built-in rival in his former bully turned climbing senpai, a mentor in his homeroom teacher and climbing coach, and a cute girl cheering him on from the sidelines. All signs point toward a clean, redemptive path to being a normal guy. But climbing doesn’t save him; it drags him deeper into himself. Mori doesn’t want to tether himself to a partner—he wants to be a solo climber, and if he could help it, he wants to be a solo climber without the lifeline of a belay rope. What follows are chapters, cleverly stylized as “climbs,” that amplify everything fundamentally broken in Mori long before they ever offer a way out—which he frequently refuses—as the manga tracks his psychological descent with grisly patience, from dropping out of high school to the isolating, obsessive adulthood that cements his effigy as the “immortal climber.”

Part of what makes The Climber so arresting is its insistence that the logic of “the ground” does not apply to the logic of the mountain. Down here, cutting a belay rope is unthinkable. Up there, if it comes down to severing that line or dying alongside your partner, you cut the rope. The manga never sensationalizes this binary choice of extremes; it simply presents the reader with the reality of a world where survival demands choices that would make no sense to anyone not already resigned to the possibility of dying for having made the climb in the first place.

To keep readers grounded without slowing the pace, each volume includes a glossary of climbing terms—clean, unobtrusive, and genuinely helpful—as well as interviews with real climbers explaining why they do what they do. But as the series reminds you, just because you can cut your ear off doesn’t make you Vincent Van Gogh. The Climber interrogates the “Why do you X?” refrain that runs through other art/athletics‑driven stories like Look Back or 100 Meters, only here the characters are often too far gone for a redemption that isn’t self‑destructive. Real egoists, the manga argues, are R.U.N.s: revolting, ugly, nauseating, and shameless—and The Climber is packed with them. 

No arc better epitomizes the ambitions and the hubris of an egoist than The Climber putting its characters through the wringer in their attempt to conquer K2, one of the five tallest mountains on Earth, and also the deadliest. Given the mountain has killed one person for every four who reached the summit since the year 2021, totalling to around 96 deaths for every estimated 800 climbers who summited by the year 2023, the odds of The Climber’s egoists being successful are dog water considering its climbing team would climb the bodies of their partners if it meant being the first to conquer its eastern face. 

The Climber is also one of those manga where the artistry illustrates its point far more effectively than dialogue ever could. For 170 chapters, The Climber’s pages capture the true devastation of an avalanche, not as the usual cloud of powder sliding politely down a mountain, but as a catastrophic force of nature rendered through panels of skyscrapers and semi‑trucks plummeting downhill at blistering, irrational speeds. It’s a visual language designed to make you feel, in your bones, how dangerous climbing really is. And Sakamoto’s artistry drives that point home, shifting effortlessly between the magical realism of trippy, ethereal, dreamlike climbing sequences and the raw, uninhibited anguish his characters endure as they bivouac on the mountain and as they curl up in a husk below it, should they be fortunate enough to descend a climb by their own power without their frozen carcasses being helicoptered from a rocky metaphor for their own hubris.

The Climber’s answer to “Why do you X?” is a deceptively simple one. Mori doesn’t climb because he loves it, nor does he do it to be the best. He does it because it’s natural to go where you feel compelled to go. And, as in life, the path that demands the most courage is, more often than not, the one you’re supposed to take. Whether that place is the zenith of a man‑killing mountain, or its nadir, where the people who love you white-knuckle it out through deafeningly silent weeks for your safe return. Along his trek, Mori metamorphosizes from an irredeemable little shit into someone worth rooting for one brutal climb at a time. 

By the time I tore through The Climber, taking many a “woosa” break, I felt I’d read a masterpiece on par with Vinland Saga. It gave me a new appreciation for climbing—and scared me straight out of ever wanting to solo climb a mountain, much less face life’s less voluntary obstacles alone.

item.title: Wccftech Awards ’25 – Best Games of 2025 and Most Anticipated of 2026 from Staff and Community
item.content:encoded:
Following the conclusion of the staff and community polls, it is time to declare the winners of the Wccftech Awards '25, which include the best games of 2025 and most anticipated titles of 2026, based on the nominees from our genre lists.

Let's begin with the results of our best games of 2025 polls. When it comes to last year's releases, the Wccftech staff and our community agreed on practically every winner except for a single category, Strategy and Simulation, with our staff giving the award to Square Enix's Final Fantasy Tactics - Ivalice Chronicles, while our community preferred Slipgate's Tempest Rising.

The clear winner is, to the surprise of absolutely nobody at this point, Sandfall's Clair Obscur: Expedition 33, which walks away with four prizes: best indie game and Game of the Year from both staff and community.

The universally acclaimed game did, however, lose to Warhorse's Kingdom Come: Deliverance II in the best RPG category. Other multi-winners in the Wccftech Awards '25 include Sucker Punch's Ghost of Yotei in the action category, Team Cherry's Hollow Knight: Silksong in the platform category, Nintendo's Mario Kart World in the sports/racing category, AdHoc Studio's Dispatch in the adventure category, EA's Battlefield 6 in the shooter category, KONAMI's Silent Hill f in the horror category, KOF Studio's Fatal Fury: City of Wolves in the fighting category, Embark's ARC Raiders in the multiplayer category, and NEOWIZ's Lies of P: Overture in the DLC/expansion category.

While 2025 was essentially the year of the indie-ish, 2026 looks a lot more centered around triple-A releases, featuring heavyweight returns from triple-A developers, franchises, or both.

When it comes to the Wccftech staff and community 2026 polls, they were a fair bit more discordant than the 2025 polls, but that is to be expected given that we're talking about unreleased games. Our own staff also voted differently in a few categories, resulting in a few ties at the top.

Even so, one game emerged above all the others. Yes, it's obviously Rockstar's Grand Theft Auto 6, which received four prizes: most anticipated action game from the community, most anticipated multiplayer from the community, and most anticipated overall from both staff (tied) and community. The runner-up for most anticipated prizes is CAPCOM's Resident Evil Requiem, which got three: most anticipated horror game from both staff and community, and most anticipated overall from the staff (tied).

The other multi-winners were Playground's Fable (in the RPG category) and Forza Horizon 6 (in sports/racing), The Coalition's Gears of War: E-Day (in shooter), ARC System Works' MARVEL Tōkon: Fighting Souls (in fighting), Crystal Dynamics/Flying Wild Hog's Tomb Raider: Legacy of Atlantis (in platform), the untitled STALKER 2 DLC (in expansion), Creative Assembly's Total War: Warhammer 40,000 (in strategy/simulation), and Big Bad Wolf's Cthulhu: The Cosmic Abyss (in adventure).

item.title: Life is Strange will bring the Max and Chloe story to an end in new game
item.content:encoded:
Andrew Webster

is an entertainment editor covering streaming, virtual worlds, and every single Pokémon video game. Andrew joined The Verge in 2012, writing over 4,000 stories.

A little over a decade ago, Life is Strange burst onto the scene with a unique blend of teen drama and interactive storytelling. That first game told the story of Max Caulfield, who had the supernatural ability to reverse time, and her best friend Chloe Price. Now developer Deck Nine Games is finally bringing their story to an end with a new game called Reunion.

The latest entry in the series follows 2024’s Double Exposure, which similarly continued Max’s story from the original game. The developer describes Reunion as the “emotional conclusion of the Max and Chloe saga.” Players will have three days to attempt to avoid a fire at their old college, where Max is now a teacher. Here’s the basic set-up:

Returning from a weekend away, Max finds her beloved Caledon ablaze, as a raging inferno destroys the hallowed grounds and ends the lives of Max’s friends, students, and faculty alike. Max only escapes the devastation due to her Rewind power — returning from the original Life is Strange — a supernatural ability that lets her reverse time. Jumping back in time through a selfie, Max now has just three days to work out how the fire began. Can she make the most of her second chance to prevent this fiery disaster?

The twist is that both characters will be playable for the first time. While Max retains her time travel power, Chloe’s skill is her back talk and attitude, which can apparently do a hella good job of dealing with suspects.

Of course, while Reunion marks the end of this particular storyline, that doesn’t necessarily mean Life is Strange won’t continue. The series has adopted something of an anthology format, with several games — Life is Strange 2 and Life is Strange: True Colors — telling all new stories within the same themes and gameplay structure.

It appears that Life is Strange: Reunion won’t be an episodic release — publisher Square Enix describes it as “a full-length adventure” — and it’s launching on March 26th on the PS5, Xbox, and PC.

Follow topics and authors from this story to see more like this in your personalized homepage feed and to receive email updates.

  • Andrew Webster


https://www.theverge.com/games/864438/life-is-strange-reunion-release-date-max-chloe

item.title: New Witcher 3 Online Mod Lets You Hang Together With Friends
item.content:encoded:
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a fantastic single-player open-world RPG. One of the best ever made. And yet the incredibly detailed and lively world of the game would make for the perfect place to hang out with some friends. And thanks to a new mod, that dream can now be made real on PC.

As spotted by Polygon, Witcher Online is a new free mod for the PC version of The Witcher 3 that adds online multiplayer for up to five players. The mod launched earlier this month and is available now on Nexus Mods and was created by user Rejuvenate. Here’s a trailer for the mod, which shows off what’s possible when five Geralts are hanging out together:

To play Witcher Online, you’ll need to download and install the mod and own a “non-pirated” PC copy of the latest version of The Witcher 3 from either Steam or GOG.

The mod lets players customize their Geralt or use custom player characters while hanging out online. Folks can also relax and chill in the game’s various taverns using a separate Witcher 3 mod, Chill Out, which is fully supported by Witcher Online. You and a few friends can play through all of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt using this mod. However, there are a few caveats. While the mod does sync all character animations, equipment, and combat across multiple players, you won’t be able to help other players fight monsters or complete quests, so the mod creator recommends you quest together and all “try to complete objectives at the same time as each other throughout the storyline.”

But really, while you can go out and complete quests, Witcher Online seems more like a mod designed to let friends hang out in The Witcher 3‘s fantasy world and just enjoy the vibes while causing some random chaos or mayhem. And because this mod is free to access, I don’t think developers CDPR are going to go after it like the company recently did with a Cyberpunk 2077 VR mod.



https://kotaku.com/new-witcher-3-online-mod-lets-you-hang-together-with-friends-2000661320
